item.title: Logical operator help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

&& is a shortcut for & and || is a shortcut for |.

The and & operator checks if both values are true. If one of the two values are false, then the final product will be false. The && operator checks if the first value is true or false. If the first value is true, it will also check the second value.

The or | operator checks if both values are false. If one of the two values are true, then the final product will be false. The || operator checks the first value to be false, before continuing to check the second value.

The inverse ! operator will make a true boolean, false and a false boolean, true.

Read full topic

item.title: Logical operator help
item.dc:creator: @dogzound5 dogzound5@gmail.com
item.description:
@dogzound5 wrote:

OK I was looking at a tutorial and this was a coded example to understand logical operators.

[code]public class LogicalOperatorsDemo {

public LogicalOperatorsDemo() {
	boolean x = true;
	boolean y = false;
	System.out.println("x & y : " + (x & y));
	System.out.println("x && y : " + (x && y));
	System.out.println("x | y : " + (x | y));
	System.out.println("x || y: " + (x || y));
	System.out.println("x ^ y : " + (x ^ y));
	System.out.println("!x : " + (!x));
}
public static void main(String args[]) {
	new LogicalOperatorsDemo();
}

}[/code]

I am really confused about it though because I don’t understand how one can equal true or false if both boolean variables equal the opposite. Someone who can help me understand it would be great!!!

Read full topic
